reviewText: I watched this as a child & loved it & I'm so glad it's back for more generations to love! My 18 month old son loves this movie & watches it over & over. He is glued to the tv when this is on & dances to the music. Unfortunately, Elmo is not in this, but all the original Sesame Street characters are. This brings back great memories & I love starting new ones with my family. It's a cute story that starts when Oscar tells Big Bird that Santa can't fit down the chimney so there will be no presents on Christmas morning. So Big Bird goes on a mission to find out how Santa gets down the chimney. The music in this movie is great & it's so much fun to watch!

reviewText: First off, viewers must be aware that this is Sesame Street from the 1970's.  Many of your child's favorite characters weren't "born" yet.  Also, remember that back then Sesame Street was a little edgier in that Oscar was seemingly being a little mean to Big Bird, teasing him about Santa Claus and how no one would get presents.  He also didn't hesitate to talk about Santa's weight in a not very "PC" manner.  Once those two facts are accepted, this is classic Sesame Street fun and sentiment.  Bert and Ernie find themselves acting out The Gift of the Magi, with the Jewish Mr. Hooper providing the most heartwarming moment of the film and demonstrating the best of sentiments.  I Hate Christmas, sung by Oscar, harkens back to what Sesame Street was back then in that it is just plain funny, but also shows what they (sadly) would never get away with in these ultra-sensitive days.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I cannot begin to express how happy I am that they make this on DVD. This was one of my (and my sister's) favorite Christmas specials. Growing up in the 80s they showed it every year around the holidays and we had it taped on VHS. Last year I found it online and watched it and was pleasantly surprised by how timeless it seemed. While clothing and hair look dated, the dialog and story are not. This is a classic...before Sesame Street got all politically correct. Here we find Cookie Monster still gobbling up cookies by the dozen and Oscar still grouchy and slightly sarcastic (and no annoying little red beast anywhere to be seen!) The story is sweet and revolves around Big Bird trying to figure out how Santa fits down the chimney. There is a sweet side story re-telling "The Gift of the Magi" with Bert and Ernie. The song "Keep Christmas WIth You" featured in this show is wonderful- catchy and sweet. I've purchased this so that I can share it with my nephew in hopes that it can become one of his favorite Christmas specials, since it is already loved by his mommy and auntie.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I never cease to be amused when I occasionally watch the Sesame Street specials like Don't Eat the Pictures (which still hasn't been released to DVD!), Follow That Bird, Big Bird in China, or this hour-long special, Christmas Eve on Sesame Street.  I like the tunes of the songs on this special, and the words fit the music well.  I also like the balance of short incidents (Cookie Monster or Ernie & Bert) and a continuous story (involving Big Bird).  The story involves Big Bird trying to figure out how Santa gets through the chimney, thanks to Oscar the Grouch working him up into a panic.  I really like Oscar's song about hating Christmas.  It's funny, and has some unintended truth to its words!  Oscar sings about hating Christmas festivity, and I must confess that I also get sick of the unnatural hype of the "Christmas season"--not from the extreme quantity of merchandise so much as the pageantry of everyone pretending to be happier than they are and nicer than they are, and obsessing about creating the perfect mood.  Ignore all your problems for one glorious month, and spend all you want, and put on a smile!  Everyone loves everyone--and then forgets it the next week, inevitably.  Oscar's song about hating Christmas has a funny tune, funny words, and he does mean things to people during the song that are funny to watch.  It's fun to root for him sometimes!  It's hard to imagine him NOT being there, because it'd be extremely annoying to have Big Bird have no opponent.If I could, I'd add a 6th star because this has a meaningful touch of beneficial content that goes beyond the typical fare of "Christmas is the time for giving and caring".  Thematically, there's a nice touch in this special that presents a healthy role model, of another adult telling the Jewish shopkeeper Mr. Hooper "Happy Hanukkah" and Mr. Hooper responding back with a "Merry Christmas".  They respect each other even though they're of different religions, because they have the same values about morality.  That is the kind of thoughtful content that more programs, for ALL ages, need to have.
summary: A bit of nostalgia, with an unexpected plus in its thoughtful content

reviewerName: Don't tread on me "Defending the Conservative...
reviewText: This is a true classic.  Who remembers Mr. Hooper?  For those of us who remember watching Sesame Street and Electric Company when they first started, this is one for your collection!This takes you back to the days before Sesame Street got all Politically Corrected up.  There is one truly classic scene.  Bob wishes Mr. Hooper a Happy Hannukah.  Mr. Hooper returns the greeting with a Merry Christmas <gasp>.  No big deal.  No federal law suits.  No sensitivity training for anybody.Oscar the Grouch is the way Oscar is meant to be.  Grouchy.  he does his best to ruin Big Bird's Christmas.  It is something to watch Kermit with Jim Henson's voice - something definitely missed.  Far better than Elmo Saves Christmas.  (A Christmas show with Harvey Fierstein should be burned.)
summary: Sesame Street - the way it was and should still be

reviewText: I have been watching "Christmas Eve on Sesame Street" ever since my parents taped this for me and my sisters sometime in the 1980's (although I'm not sure exactly when). I'm glad I found this DVD, because the video copy I have has definitely seen better days!This program was made in the 1970's, but I don't feel as though it's dated. Kudos for releasing it just the way it was, and not making an updated version of this.***WARNING: FOLLOWING MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS***The story starts out at a skating party, where Oscar the Grouch asks that fateful question: "How does Santa Claus get down all those skinny little chimneys?" Big Bird and his friend, Patty, have to find out right away! So Kermit the Frog and Grover ask some kids how they think Santa does it (some of the kids responses are really interesting).Another storyline is a classic take of the O. Henry story, "Gift of the Magi" where Bert and Ernie are trying to think of what to give each other for Christmas. Neither of them have any money so they each trade their most prized possessions to Mr. Hooper to get each other a present.One of my absolute favorite parts of this whole special is Cookie Monster writing a letter to Santa. Or at least trying to. I won't go into great detail about this one, you and your kids just HAVE to see it for yourselves!***END OF OVERVIEW***Anyway, this has always been one of my favorite Christmas programs, and I think it's great for kids of any age.

reviewText: I have been a huge Sesame Street fan since birth (yep since the 70's). And now that I am a Mom, my 24 month old daughter is becoming a big fan too. I received this DVD as a gift, and as she and I watched it together, I got very emotional, remembering how I watched it as a child, and now my child is watching it with me!! It's a classic, the stories and songs are perfect for the holidays. It doesn't have Elmo in it (of course, it's 10 years too early!), so it isn't my daughter's absolute favorite, but it's close. Her 2nd favorite SS character is Big Bird, and he's the star in this one, which she loves. And it is definitely MY absolute favorite of all her holiday videos!! (but if you're sentimental, keep the tissues handy, Mr. Hooper is in this one!) We love it, and recommend it to any Sesame Street fan.

reviewText: When I was young, this wonderful Christmas special was played every year on TV on Christmas Eve day.  However, the past two years it was replaced with various specials featuring "hipper" animated characters, and I couldn't find it.  I was shocked to even learn it was still being sold, and very excited!If you or your children have ever watched Sesame Street, this video is a MUST OWN.  Although it doesn't feature the newer characters, there is plenty of Bert, Ernie, Big Bird, Oscar, Cookie Monster, and of course all the people in the cast that I was familiar with as a young child.  This video makes me laugh to this day!  It features a variety of charming and funny scenes, and keeps you involved from the very beginning when the whole Sesame Street gang goes ice skating.This video, although great for kids, will make you laugh along with them as you watch it!

reviewText: I absolutely love this video. The songs are beautiful, the characters are endearing and hilarious and most of all this story teaches a good lesson: that it is more important to give than receive and that Christmas is not about getting presents, trees and food but it is about family and being together and that is what Christmas is all about. Awesome video for all ages, go and buy it and it will help you realize the true meaning of Christmas in this material world.
summary: A great christmas video with a great message

reviewText: My 4 year old son really enjoyed watching this 1978 Christmas special.  However, when he asked me "Where's Elmo?" I started to laugh and I told him that the movie came out before Elmo was born!  Also, there was another scene where Cookie Monster ate the typewriter on which he was attempting to type a letter to Santa.  Confused, (this time by the contraption that Cookie Monster was destroying), my son pointed and asked "What's that?"  It had never occurred to me that in our hi-tech communications world of today, my son would have no concept of the antiquated typewriter.  It was an interesting moment that made me feel a little old!It was truly refreshing to watch a pre-Elmo Sesame Street special.  I don't dislike Elmo, but his over saturating and ubiquitous presence can be annoying at times.  Moreover, I truly feel that during the era of this film, the Sesame Street writers did a good job of keeping adults entertained as well - similar to today's Pixar projects in some ways - with quips and bits of humor that would "go over" young children's heads.  Unfortunately, Sesame Street today probably could not get away with Big Bird referring to Santa Claus as being "fat," or with the caustic nature of the 1970's Oscar the Grouch, without someone complaining to the network.It was also nice to see Mr. Hooper again - the little Jewish shopkeeper, beloved as much as any of the Muppets of the time.  He, along with Bert and Ernie recreate a touching and memorable version of "The Gift of the Magi."The picture on the front of the VHS version of the film, with Big Bird sitting on a snowy rooftop waiting to see how Santa manages to get down the chimney, is much better than the generic cover picture for the DVD.  They should have continued to use the original image.This truly is a great Christmas special, and a nice piece of nostalgia...I think we'll watch it again tonight!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Unlike the "wanna-be-hip" mindset so present in the new Sesame Street, this is classic Sesame Street at its finest and it entertains children of all ages.I remember seeing this when it was still pretty new, and fell in love with it ever since.Big Bird decides to find out how Santa comes down the chimney and (befitting the urban angle which was the original intention of the show) how he will get down the apartment buildings that are clearly without the fireplaces found in the suburbs or luxury apartments.The suspense created by Big Bird's quest is intriguing enough for older viewers without being scary for younger children (who would otherwise worry about Santa's well being)and really needs to be shown every christmas.

reviewText: This is one of the few dvds I own of Sesame Street and the other one that I own of Sesame Street is Sesame Street Presents: Follow That Bird. Sesame Street has been on the air since the late 60's (and I think this is now the only longest show ever). Christmas Eve on Sesame Street starts in a christmas skating party in a skating rink near Sesame Street. And things are going good, Ernie nad friends play hockey with Bert's shoe as the hockey puck plus the friends are alos busy having a great time on the ice. Until Oscar is thrown all the way out the door down the stairs and out of out of the bulding. Big Bird and a kid goe to Oscar and he pops a question to Big Bird. His question is how does Santa Clause get down the skinny chimneys and also tels Big Bird that if Santa can't that there will be no Christmas presents under the tree. Plus if you don't think that is enough to have some fun every Christmas, this special has songs to listen to (even sing-along if you want). The songs are Feliz Navidad, A True Blue Miracle, Keep Christmas With You (All Though The Year), I Hate Christmas, and Have Yourself A Merry Little Christmas. The best song in here (in my opinion) is Keep Christmas With You (All Though The Year). The only recored song in this special is Feliz Navidad and the rest are sung by the residents of Sesame Strett from Bert and Erine to Oscar. The song Bert and Erine sing is Have Yourself A Merry Little Christmas.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I love love love Christmas Eve on Sesame Street. It doesn't feel like Christmas to me until I hear "Keep Christmas with you all thru the year..." I remember watching this when I was a little girl and checking the TV book with every Sunday paper to be sure not to miss it every holiday season.  When my mom finally taped it, I remember asking to watch it everyday. It is such a good wholesome movie which shows about giving (not receiving) and not really questioning how Santa does it - he just does somehow. It was amazing to me as a kid and now my 4 yr old daughter loves it just as much. My favorite part as a kid was watching Cookie try to contact Santa - I giggled and giggled. Now it is my daughters favorite part too, she also loves when Oscar says "Ding Dong, your wrong" I have never heard her belly laugh like that before and she always makes me replay it. As an adult, I love the part when the kids trying to figure out how Santa gets into the house - classic. I hope they never EVER mess with this version. It is just perfect.
Title: N/A

reviewText: For years I had a vague memory of a Sesame Street Christmas episode in which Ernie and Bert enacted their own version of O. Henry's "Gift of the Magi." Ernie traded his Rubber Duckie for a box to put Bert's paperclip collection in and Bert traded his paperclip collection for a tray to put Ernie's Rubber Duckie on. Luckily, Mr. Hooper sets everything right and it's a merry Christmas on Sesame Street. This special also shows Big Bird who is very concerned about how Santa is going to fit down all those chimneys (Thanks to Oscar!) and the Cookie Monster who gets a little carried away when trying to write a letter to Santa. This one is a must for all Sesame Street lovers out there...which, let's face it, is pretty much all of us.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Having been a huge Sesame Street fan during the 70s (born in 1967), I was thrilled to see this title for sale. It was great to see Mr. Hooper, David, and some of the other long departed characters.It would have been worth it just for the joy of revisiting some childhood memories. But the genuinely touching subplot of Ernie and Bert's schemes to surprise each other with the perfect gift made this a treasure that I will watch again and again, and share with my son when he is old enough.Throw in Emmet Otter's Jug Band Christmas, and you have a pair of Jim Henson Christmas specials with enough Christmas spirit to warm the coldest December night.
summary: Great bit of nostalgia, surprisingly touching
Title: N/A
